questions.text: Identify the anatomical variation of the pinna given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Darwin's Tubercle :

  • It is an anatomical variation.
  • It is not a disease.
  • It is a conical elevation on the helix.
  • It shows that humans are descended from Apes.

Explanation of other options:

Stahl's ear(Option B): Also known as Spock ear - characterised by an extra cartilage fold, giving the ear a pointed shape.

Satyr ear(Option C): A misnomer, sometimes used to describe an ear with a pointed or upturned helix, resembling mythological satyrs.

Cup ear(Option D): A congenital deformity where the ear is small, cup-shaped, and protruding due to abnormal cartilage.

questions.text: A patient has a deformed pinna as shown in the image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cauliflower ear:

  • Cauliflower ear is a deformity of the pinna (external ear) caused by repeated trauma or blunt injury to the ear, causing hematoma, commonly seen in wrestlers, boxers, and rugby players.
  • The trauma causes a hematoma between the cartilage and skin, leading to fibrosis and permanent thickening/deformity if untreated.
  • It gives the ear a lumpy, swollen appearance, resembling a cauliflower.
  • Incision, drainage and pressure bandage is the best way of managing the Hematoma, in which repeated hematomas cause cauliflower ear, otoplasty can be done.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Bat ear(Option A): Refers to protruding ears due to an underdeveloped antihelical fold or large concha, not due to trauma. The ideal management is Cosmetic surgery of the pinna called Otoplasty. Ideal age of otoplasty ≥ 6 yrs, because the graft is to be taken from costal cartilage that is usually fully developed after 6 years of age.
  • Tropical ear(Option C): Not a standard medical term for a deformity.
  • Surfer ear(Option D): Refers to exostosis (bony growths) in the ear canal due to cold water exposure, not affecting the pinna's shape.

questions.text: Van der Hoeve syndrome includes all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Van Der Hoeve Syndrome:

Most commonly caused by mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, which encode type I collagen. It consists of a triad of:

  • Otosclerosis(Option D ruled out)
  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta(Option A ruled out)
  • Blue Sclera(Option B ruled out)

Hence, iritis is not a part of it.

questions.text:
All are ototoxic drugs except
1. Deferoxamine
2. Aspirin
3. Furosemide
4. Cisplatin
5. Methotrexate
6. Chloroquine
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methotrexate is not an ototoxic drug.

Ototoxic Drugs:

  • Aminoglycosides
  • Antimalarial drugs(Chloroquine)
  • Analgesics(Aspirin)(Option C ruled out)
  • Vancomycin
  • Cytotoxic drugs(Cisplatin)
  • Diuretics(Furosemide)(Option A ruled out)
  • Erythromycin
  • Azithromycin
  • Desferoxamine(Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Hearing loss on the right side is 60 dB, 60dB and 90 dB on 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz, respectively. Hearing loss on the left side is 30dB, 40dB and 50 dB on 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz, respectively. How much is the percentage of the handicapped?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To be done for both ears separately-

  • Calculate the average hearing loss.
  • Deduct 25 dB from this figure (as there is no hearing impairment up to 25dB).
  • Multiply this by 1.5 to get a percentage.

Total % of Handicap = [(better ear% x 5) + Worse ear%] / 6

In the given case,

questions.text: The hearing at which frequency is affected first in noise induced hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The audiogram in Noise Induced Hearing Loss shows a typical notch at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. It is usually symmetrical on both sides.
  • It is known as the Acoustic dip.
  • At this stage, the patient complains of high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in noisy surroundings, but no difficulty in day-to-day hearing.

questions.text: A patient of left atticoantral CSOM presents with a history of headache, vomiting and convulsions. His CT scan of the brain has revealed a Right temporal lobe abscess. What is the best surgical treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given history suggests a diagnosis of Brain Abscess. First, the brain abscess should be treated that is neurosurgical treatment(Other options ruled out).

Brain Abscess:

  • The most common site of otogenic brain abscess is the temporal lobe, and the second site is the cerebellum.

Chief complaints:

  • Patients with chronic foul-smelling ear discharge develop headache, vomiting, Convulsions in temporal abscess and cerebellar disease. Patients present with severe headache, spontaneous nystagmus and a staggering gait.

Investigation-

  • CECT brain .. It shows Ring enhancing lesions.

Treatment is Neurosurgery.

  • The treatment of the brain abscess should be prioritised, and once the patient becomes stable, MRM can be done.
